text: [Music]
hi guys will our tally on this episode
of Laura in the kitchen I want to show
you how I make my butternut squash soup
now this is my mother's recipe that I've
been eating for years and years and
years and I pretty much don't know any
other way to make it because this is
what I love you can make the same recipe
with pumpkin but I'm choosing to use
butternut squash today because that's
always available in my market so before
we get started let's go over the
ingredients you'll need some fresh
butternut squash peeled and diced you'll
need some small cut pasta fresh parsley
fresh garlic some tomato puree or any
kind of tomato product you have you can
use some leftover marinara sauce chopped
tomatoes a couple of fresh tomatoes
doesn't matter you just need some sort
of tomato product and you also need
olive oil salt pepper and water that's
it
those are your ingredients but this is
so good that nursery food for me so I
remember growing up eating so to get
started let's just go to the stove and
start cooking coz all my prep is done in
my soup pot I have about a tablespoon of
extra virgin olive oil over medium-high
heat I'm gonna add in my chopped up
garlic and I want to add it when the oil
is not super hot yet because I want the
oil to heat up with the garlic for the
garlic to really develop its flavor and
not just turn brown right away so let
that cook for about a minute or so until
the garlic is fragrant and it starts to
turn a little bit of color just gonna
put in my butternut squash give this a
toss no matter what this cook for a
couple minutes
just to give it a heads up and then I'm
gonna add my rest of my ingredients just
gonna season my butternut squash with

really nice seasoned finish then going
to add some water now you can add you
know vegetable stock if you wanted to
you could add beef meat numpy but
chicken stock if you wanted to I just
like to add water that's because when
I'm that's what my mother uses but you
can add whatever you want so now we're
gonna add in our parsley it this is so
simple one
mean really a couple little steps and
you have a great great soup our tomato
paste and now I just knocked the heat
back down to medium and I'm gonna let
this cook for about 45 minutes we're
looking for the butternut squash to be
really soft and tender and for the broth
to be a little thickened and then we're
gonna add our pasta finish the whole
thing together after 45 minutes this is
what you're looking for now all I'm
gonna do with my 1 spoon is kind of
crush some of the butternut squash
against my pot here just because my
mother did that it makes a super really
nice and creamy and I just love the
consistency but still leaving a lot of
the chunks I mean I'm only doing it
really really lightly I'm gonna put the
heat back up to medium-high and I'm
gonna add in my shortcut pops up about a
cup or so this is gonna be really nice
and thick almost like a stew consistency
rather than a thin soup and I'm also
going to season it with some salt
no more pepper because we do have pepper
already and without burning on squash so
I'm gonna do is I'm gonna let this cook
for about ten minutes just until the
pastas pretty much cook through and then
I'm gonna meet you at the counter to
taste it my soup is done and it's
exactly how it should be in my opinion
if you want it a little bit more loose
or like more of a soupy consistency
rather than a stew consistency then by
all means add more water that's the
great thing about soups and stews it's
not like baking you don't have to be
precise if you want to add some carrots
if you want to add some celery if you
want to add some onions please do this
is a stew it's not a cake batter what
you have to be precise because it's
baking its science it's you know it's
boring stuff that we don't care about
but as soon as different this is just

mean it growing up but like I said if

please make it you know add a little bit
